Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not

This course was really good. It taught me how to do many preliminary analyses in SAS. However, I really dislike the grading policy. I would have preferred rubrics with percentages.

Very great course that teaches students how to apply their skills to assess a dataset. This was probably the first useful course I took at YSPH. I am much more confident about working with SAS and knowing what to do when given a dataset. My only complaint is that the lecture notes aren't reader-friendly. Most of the notes are code so if you wanted to revisit the lecture, it's hard to follow what is going on. Lecture notes should be organized better.
Awesome.  But if not programming and stats comfortable, budget adequate time to spend a little extra time.

Strengths: 
- Highly organized 
- Labs encouraged critical thinking 
- Midterm was reflective of labs and what was learned in class
- Allowed students to develop a strong and tangible skillset by the end of the semester 

Weaknesses: 
-Grading: 3 point grading scale left little room for learning.. only complete mastery was rewarded  (2/3 seemed harsh for minor rounding errors)
Analysis of the data tables and correlating them to real world data bases was exciting and learning strength of the course.

Lack of clarity on grading between the professor and TFs was problematic. The ambiguity of "showing improvement" over the course of the semester was anxiety-inducing given the fact that labs were graded on a 3-point system, with points taken off in equal measure for serious and minor mistakes. More opportunities to show improvement or restructuring this grading system might ameliorate students' stress levels. The majority of my colleagues in this class that I have spoken with share this sentiment. 

I would have appreciated a section of the course dedicated to writing summaries. Literally a "how to write a summary" segment that includes references to examples the professor or TFs find appropriate or useful. With little background in scientific writing and quantitative coursework, this sort of "101" material would have been useful for me to learn. It's the end of the semester at this point and I still don't feel confident in my ability to write a summary. As far as I know, understanding how to do this was not a pre-req of this course.

Inconsistencies with TFs were also problematic. I found the TF for my lab section to be impatient with my lack of understanding of the course material and unhelpful in answering questions about course material, but another TF to be completely sympathetic and helpful in explaining concepts from scratch during her office hours.

Office hours with the professor were extremely helpful.

very applied way of teaching and selection of topics
large class, but well-managed, TFs could have varying knowledge-base to answer the queries
Good pace, good readings, good examples, fair labs that allowed for thinking at appropriate pace (not too fast, but moved forwards consistently).

I think it was good. At the end of the semester, I felt confident to be able to do my own analyses of data using SAS, which is way more that I felt I could do after one semester of R work. I think the labs were well designed and reflected what we learned and built on each other.
The course material was presented effectively and concepts were clear. Conducting analyses in lab reinforced the material each week. I do not believe the course needs improvement.

I appreciated this course, although I am not a "quant." This provided a good introduction to using SAS and the instructor was expert/professional in his discussion of this material. However, I felt that this course could have provided more time in lab (2 hours instead of 1) and could have been more guided. I felt like I was having to learn a lot of the material myself/looking at online resources. Also, the fact that this class only met once per week was a turn off. I would have preferred that this class was at least a 2-times-per-week class so that there were more opportunities to practice this complex material. I felt the the instructor was somewhat abrasive, but fair. As a non-quant guy, he was a little scary *but justified* about being accurate in your data analysis. I really respect him. And I really enjoyed the course.

This was an extremely hands-on, practical, skills-based course. You learn how to conduct analyses in SAS and have weekly labs where you go through the coding assignment with your teaching fellow. I learned a lot from this course and think it lays an excellent foundation for data analyses in SAS.

I learned a lot from this course. However, I do not think that taking off one whole point out of only three for minor mistakes on the labs is conducive to learning. I know that there is an emphasis on perfection, but this type of grading only leads to stress and does not create a positive learning environment.
A very solid course. I think having a little more emphasis on the interpretation of results would be nice.

I really loved SAS and felt that the way it was presented was extremely practical and easy to understand. The focus on application of coding was appropriate in that I didn't feel too bogged down in conceptual content. I'm leaving the class feeling confidence enough in SAS to advertise the skill for jobs.
Overall, great intro to SAS and epidemiology/ biostatistics class. I learned more from AAMIE than I did in my epi and biostats classes.
learned SAS

Strengths: Easy. Not too time consuming. Lecture not necessary to succeed. 

Weakness: The grading scale is a bit wonky. Every assignment out of 3 points. One mistakes dooms you.

This was a very informative class. The learning environment and teaching style are fantastic. I would highly recommend it for anyone regardless of their level of statistical understanding. I began knowing I would have to work harder to understand the underlying statistical theories some weeks but it was made very easy to understand and help was always available if needed.
Great. I have learned a fantastic skill in SAS and feel a lot more confident using it versus R from the Biostat class.

This course is a really good primer to get an introduction to SAS. I had no coding experience at all going in, and I was able to keep up. The course is structured very methodically and you learn to run a wide range of analyses. That being said, I think the lectures were too long and the labs were too short. Most students learnt the most by actually doing anyway. The lectures could have been condensed.
good course, exams really force you to learn SAS and lab gives you the necessary tools

great course to learn and practice SAS. It's very practical, as most internships/jobs ask for experiences in SAS and likely will have you do the analysis we did for the labs

the grading is confusing as grades aren't necessarily assigned. this is meant to encourage actual learning the material as opposed to preoccupation with grades, but it's stressful not knowing where I stood in the class
Scores between 2 and 3 for lab, since they translate badly into the grade even for small mistakes. More introduction to other ways to code things and why you might choose one way over another.

This course is wonderful! It really suits those without experience with SAS. This instructions are detailed and informative. However, the analytic part is somewhat not that deep, but still this course is great.
This was a great course and I learned a lot of useful skills

Best data management class. Even with prior SAS knowledge, I still found this class extremely useful. With this class you can comfortably analyze data and get it ready for publishing. This class also helped me understand some statistical concepts better than the classes dedicated to teaching said concepts.

It is a strong course. The grading for the labs is frustrating. anything less than a perfect score earns you a 2/3 which can really have a bad impact on your grade.
I also wish that the lab sessions would be structured to solve problem sets independently  because often times I felt like I gained little out of them since the Gas would just type code and the students would blindly follow
Great
Great course! I learned so much more than I expected and came out feeling confident in my SAS skills.
Good source for really using SAS. Grading for labs is a little more strict than maybe necessary.

This course stressed the importance of accuracy and preciseness. It has not only provided structured coding skills but also cultivated the habit of checking, which is of great significance in data analysis. The labs are also a good part to practice coding.
I learned a lot during this class! Its very useful if you want to perform research. The lab component is very useful and provides the tools you need to succeed.
Good overall, teaches us very important skills.
I feel extremely confident in my SAS abilities as a result of taking this course. I just wish there was an "R" equivalent.
I feel that learning to use SAS is an important skill which this course teaches.
Extremely helpful and very useful class; learned imperative skills
Good!

I learned a lot because the class forces you to which was great. Even though I still have a long way to go I feel like I now have a solid foundation in SAS for someone who had never touched it before.
Incredible professor.
Very useful SAS skills. However, grading for labs can be more lenient.

This course was great! I like everything about it. Although it was a SAS focused course, I learned a lot about managing the data. I feel myself very confident about knowing and handling the data at the end of this semester. I wish it was a fall course instead of spring. I know that some people were complaining about grading system but I can totally understand the rationale behind it; you need to be careful when working and reporting data. I feel that this meticulousness prepared me to look more carefully to the papers that I am going to read and my future publication submissions. I also improved my summary writing skills for the data outcomes. My only problem was the class size; it was so crowded.

One of the most well-taught, organized, and useful courses at YSPH! I was able to use a lot of the skills I have learned in AAMIE in another class, and it was nice to see how applicable these skills are in action. The course is well paced and the material is incredibly useful and important if one wants to work in epidemiology. I wouldn't feel confident about my foundational knowledge and skills in using analytic methods coming into my internship or writing my thesis without having taken this course! While the course was a bit stressful sometimes, especially with the expectation on attention to details, I came to appreciate it because in a research setting, one cannot afford to make mistakes that jeopardize findings. The course was well paced and exams were fair game. The TFs were also very helpful in office hours and seem to care about the students' performance.

Strengths - very organized, clear expectations, clear lines of communication with TFs and instructor. Learn how to effectively use SAS. 
Weaknesses - I guess you could say large class size? But I think large lecture style for learning a statistical program is fine.

There are a number of strengths of this course, including the pacing of content throughout the course, feedback provided on lab assignments each week, and the self-paced nature of exams. The pacing of the course was effective, as students are presented with easily decipherable material early on, and the difficulty of the course progresses as additional material is presented. The feedback provided on each lab assignment was helpful for understanding where errors were made, and what improvements could be made in coding. I enjoyed the self-paced, take home exams for the midterm and the final exam. This presents a real-world opportunity to understand and apply coding knowledge and statistical analysis on larger projects. On the other hand, I believe students should be provided with three take home exams, as opposed to two. Doing so would provide students with additional feedback to gauge their performance, and the exams are reflective of small projects that students would actually be working on for an employer. The application of knowledge in this setting is fundamental to mastery of the content. Further, this would split 80% of the course grade among three exams (e.g. 15%, 25%, 40%), as opposed to 30% and 50% currently. 

The convoluted structure of grading for the course was a weakness. Students were provided with "ballpark" estimates of their midterm grades, and official grades for the midterm were never posted on Canvas. Additionally, lab assignments are graded out of a total of 3 points. A very minor error (including 1 typo in a multi-page document), or a number of errors, resulted in 1 point being taken off. 2 points were taken off for a number of extensive errors. I believe students should be graded on 0.5 point increments, as there is a not a proportional decrease in quality between 1 point and 2 points off an assignment. Additionally, taking 1 point off of an assignment for a student that made a small error, vs. 1 point off for a student who made multiple errors does not add up.
a good and useful course
Excellent course
Wish there was a greater distribution in midterm scores so that losing one point wasnt the difference between honors and high pass
This class was very applicable and taught the foundations of statistical analysis using SAS.
This class truly challenges you, and at the end you are able to code and understand the meaning and implications for your output .
learn much knowledge about gene. Group discussion is very interesting

I thought it was a great course. I learned so much about SAS and about research/scientific writing. Strengths are definitely the labs. Applying what I learned in class was a great way to flex muscles. A weakness of the course was sometimes the lectures were monotonous. It would be cool if Mayur did some in-class examples on SAS to showcase what he is talking about in real time. It would also be beneficial if Mayur provided general interpretations for statistical analyses because every lab required different interpretations that were not generalizable to specific lab meetings.
Made SAS very understandable and approachable.

Strengths - organization, step by step guide to SAS
Weaknesses - Lacking in creativity and chances for being graded beyond labs and exams

Highly structured; excellent examples of relevance to epidemiology. Easily the most practical and enjoyable class at YSPH.

Would have recommended 2 smaller lecture sections just because the large # of students got quite distracting with all the different googled screens. Would also have recommended (particularly during the first half of the course) more extensive articulation of what each of the calculations (e.g. OR, RR, HR) meant for the descriptive paragraphs, which would guide understanding.
I don't think TF's grading system was fair.

This course is great. I feel like I have a strong basis of SAS knowledge. Within the semester, I feel like I can do most basic SAS coding. The labs are extremely helpful in applying the knowledge learned in class. I think that the labs are some of the most useful parts of the course. It would almost be more beneficial in class to write the code out together on different projects. For example, if we applied our learning during class time by working on a dataset. The strength of this course is the amount of material that you learn.
Good course! Would love the lectures to include sections where you code along with Mayur, rather than looking at code on slides.
This is a really helpful course for understanding SAS and statistical analytics in epidemiology.
Mayurs notes are everything. Try not to miss class and labs because thats where a lot of the skills are taught and learned. Honestly, its a very hard class but you do walk out knowing how to use SAS.

labs were not hand holding but helped walk through the code at the same time so I was not completely lost which helped me actually learn it. When it came time to do the midterm and then final, I definitely spent more time than was expected but I felt I learned the coding at that point and feel comfortable with SAS at this point. For that I feel this class was taught extremely well.
Strengths: Lectures are easy to understand and the labs make a lot of sense. My TF was also excellent and very helpful. SAS is also extremely user-friendly.

This class provided a solid foundation for using SAS to apply lessons from Epi 1 and Biostats 1. I came in with no SAS background and now feel very confident importing data, coding variables, and running and interpreting analyses. My TF was supportive, engaging, and always willing to answer questions in lab or office hours. 

I felt that a 2-hour lecture was a bit long for the course (and the 1 hour lab could perhaps be longer), but my guess is that is an unchangeable feature of the class. Another weakness is that grading sometimes felt inconsistent (i.e. I wasn't really sure what qualified as a 2 vs. a 3) -- so maybe lab grading could be better delineated by TFs or Mayur.
Great course. Presented really well.
good

Strengths: One of the best courses at YSPH.  It was a practical course for not only learning SAS but for how to conduct a statistical analysis of datasets.  

Weaknesses: Grades were given based on perfection as opposed to mastery of the course material.  Would have been helpful to go over how to write summaries.
Excellent course. Great teaching materials and methods. I enjoyed the lab very much. It supplemented the lectures very well.

This was a great course and should honestly be required for any student who wishes to do any form of data analysis. For health policy students we have a methods health research class that I think would be better replaced by this class.

Strengths: The professor, the labs
Weaknesses: The homeworks were graded to harshly

The course is a great introduction to SAS. Lab sections are especially useful in allowing allowing students to perform actions learned in lecture. Lecture could be more engaging. The lectures were just showing examples on slides with very good instruction verbally, but they could get dry and repetitive in a  way that made focusing hard at times. Also, some of the slides and examples were pretty old, so maybe a refreshing with more current versions of SAS and appropriate examples would be helpful.

Strengths include ensuring that all students are provided with SAS fundamentals/basic SAS knowledge in the beginning of the class, the reasonable pace at which the material is taught, and the practical application of lecture material in labs that build upon each other over the semester. No weaknesses.
Strengths: helped to solidify SAS skills from previous courses and liked that the course went through basic analytic tests that would be used for research papers.
excellent class

Dr. Desai is a very engaging instructor. He answers questions well and provides an inclusive learning environment. He also has a great sense of humor which I think keeps students awake during class. However, I think sometimes he can be too rigid on evaluation criteria. I feel that there might be a better way to grade SAS competency rather than taking off points for mistyping or mistranscribing numbers.
great professor! Does a good job presenting codes in class in a way that isn't too technical and is engaging

Great instructor who cares about his students and their learning a lot! Really loved having Dr. Desai teach this course. My only complaint that it is hard to re-read the lecture notes to better understand content since most of the slides are SAS output without text explanations.
Awesome!

Strengths: 
- approachable 
- highly knowledgeable 
- engaging examples

Dr Desai is an excellent and engaging instructor who is excellent in taking in the students questions and incorporating them into the course. He make hte dry material come alive, makes us laugh with his wit, clear in his communications at the same time encouraging us to think critically.

One-on-one instruction in office hours was extremely helpful. That said, listening to students and checking in to make sure they are understanding material during office hours would be appreciated. As a student I find that allowing space for confusion and providing a comfortable atmosphere for asking questions (without feeling like I'm interrupting, which I often did) are both important to the learning process.

I appreciated the very prompt responses to all of the e-mails I sent.

I might suggest staying a bit more on track when it comes to lectures and explaining concepts. There was occasionally a tendency to get sidetracked with anecdotes that were, for me as a student struggling with the course material, somewhat distracting. I occasionally felt as though the limited time during office hours was sucked up by lengthy commentary as well.

Conscientiousness about example studies and current public health vernacular would also be appreciated (i.e. the example referencing deaths by suicide).
excellent teacher! very practical and funny, helpful
Excellent, Great examples from real world included in all examples. Important to connect labs/lectures to real world.

Mayur clearly cares about his students, and wants them to do well-not just in the course but in life in general as scientists and epidemiologists. He had a lot of good suggestions and ideas. I think he was a really good professor and I would definitely take another class by him.
Professor Desai was clear and engaging during lectures. I do not have any suggestions for improvement.

Great professor. I would appreciate more time in lab/more time for practice in class with the code. It might be nice to have class 2 days a week as well. Otherwise, great course. Very pragmatic. I learned a lot.

Dr. Desai is clear, funny, and no-nonsense. The course isn't terribly engaging considering you are just going over code for 2 hours, but he makes a big effort to make it enjoyable. He talked about real-world studies often, and I enjoyed the connections.

I enjoyed the professor's step-by-step teaching in how to code. I learned a lot from this teaching style. However, I think he could spend a little less time in class talking about how perfect our tables need to be to avoid getting our paper rejected from JAMA. I have also heard from a few other students that he has made insensitive remarks when they go to him asking for help, so I avoided making an appointment with him for office hours this semester. Also, sometimes it seemed like he was trying to use up class time when he didn't have another topic to introduce, so it was difficult to stay focused.

Professor Desai was great- really straightforward and detail-oriented in terms of explaining the purpose of each tiny piece of coding in a way that was easily digestible. Sometimes he was a little too sarcastic, literally constantly saying that he doesn't care about anything other than right or wrong. He also chose a few really bad examples to use in class that were just socially inappropriate.
Just 100% awesome. I loved his teaching style and can't think of anything to improve.
Good and cares about students.

Strength: Pretty good at explaining things 

Weakness: Came off as condescending at times.  Left a pretty bad taste in my mouth. I wanted to like him but he was smarmy.

Amazing instructor. Very engaging and teaches in a way that makes everything easy to follow. He was always making sure that every point was understood and always had time for questions to make sure we were all on the same page. He was very approachable which made the learning experience relaxed and interesting.
Great Professor. A true mentor.
Dr. Desai is a great professor! He was good at explaining things, and I think it's very impressive that he managed to hold everyone's attention with a fairly dry topic.
little too parent-like (I don't appreciate being preemptively condoned for something I have never done - cheating on an exam) but definitely helpful/clear in expectations and lectures

Mayur reminds me of my father. he's funny and is very knowledgeable. He's more than willing to answer questions in class and allows office hours by appointment. He's also very intimidating so I never had the courage to ask questions, perhaps because he is so brilliant. Sometimes he does go on rather lengthy tangents.
Could be a little more approachable
The instructor gives detailed clarification of questions and can explains every notions and methods clearly.
He's a great instructor and very energetic. Always supportive of his students
Wonderful instructor. Lectures are clear and concise. He uses humor to create a warm learning environment.
Great instructor, very funny and makes lectures colorful.
Great and fun teacher
Professor Desai is a great professor! He is funny, welcoming, and very encouraging and supportive of students.
Good professor, open to students and questions.

I like Prof Desai so much! He's humorous. On the same time, he attached much attention to outcomes. Not only the outcome of the classes, but also our analyzing outcomes.  His lectures are clear and easy to absorb. His high standard of accuracy also encouraged us to be responsible for the outcomes of our works.
Mayur is fantastic, funny, engaging, and explains difficult concepts and SAS in a way that enables anyone to understand!
Good job teaching.
Prof. Desai is so nice and patient.
Professor Desai teaches SAS in a way that is actually applicable to real-world scenarios and I now feel as though I can apply what I have learned in my own research.

The lectures can feel long considering that they are based on teaching code which can be difficult to just learn in a lecture and not actively try. However, Professor Desai makes it engaging and applies real examples such as research studies.

I thought Mayur was a very good instructor and taught the material well. At times during some lectures I felt he made a few insensitive comments such as covering suicide data but he has since apologized for that which I appreciated.
This professor was very helpful and always willing to provide feedback/answer questions.
Good, but he often scolded the entire class for things others did. He frequently lectured us like we were disobedient children. I think he was trying to be funny but it was often uncomfortable.
Mayur is great-super approachable, makes class interesting and very knowledgable
Professor Desai is one of the best professors at YSPH.
Very engaging instructor.

Dr. Desai is a great teacher for sure! He knows what he is talking about, he emphasizes the critical points very properly, uses the time very effectively. The assignments and the exams were so well-structured. Do I need to mention his sense of humor? I am so happy that I took his class

Dr. Desai's is one of the best lecturers at YSPH! His slides are incredibly organized and useful for exams and lab assignments. His instructions were also clear and fairly straightforward. Sometimes though I feel that the course is a bit stressful. While I agree 100% that cheating is inexcusable in all circumstances, I don't agree with the method of reiterating the message and going over a list of specific coding errors students will be penalized for as opposed to giving more positive words of encouragement before an exam. This method created a certain level of fear and anxiety among students, which I find not very productive during exams. I understand that people have cheated and made a lot of coding errors in the past and that there should be repercussions for every category of action. I also understand that the teaching team does not want anyone to cheat, but I also think that the instructor is not testing students' knowledge and skills in good faith if they are giving students an impression that they expect some of them will do something wrong, be it cheating or making mistakes. A written grading rubric would clear things up and make the situation less stressful for both the teaching team and the students! I think graduate students are all adults and if someone cheats, they should know that they will face consequences sooner or later. But overall, I found Dr. Desai's teaching very effective, and I will continue using his slides for my future research work!
Mayur is a great instructor - very clear, knowledgeable, and passionate about the subject.

Mayur is a great instructor. He is personable, and presents the content of the course and SAS code in an enjoyable way. Making coding and statistical analysis interesting is a great talent. I like his personality, he is genuinely interested in his students, and he wants to help students understand the course material.

There are several things that I hope improve in the future. Mayur was not very responsive to emails - he didn't respond to emails at all, or took upwards of a week to respond. This is unacceptable for students who need to communicate with him. Additionally, he can sometimes say things that come across as abrasive, however I believe he is not trying to offend anyone.
he's really great and friendly
Excellent instructor. 5 stars.
Dr. Desai was very helpful whenever a question came up and provided real world examples to illustrate his points. He's a great teacher!

Strength: He is very knowledgeable and helpful. 
Weaknesses: A few of his examples and language was not sensitive to the lived experiences of those in the class. His choice to use an example about suicide and his language at times surrounding those who are overweight/obese was insensitive and surprising as he works in the public health sphere. He did apologize for his statements surrounding the suicide example, which was appreciated.
very nice professor
He is awesome!
One of the best faculty at YSPH. Very approachable and knowledgeable.
Engaging and excited about the material.
Articulate, engaging, structured. Overall, excellent educator.
He is a great instructor. AAMIE was definitely my favorite class!
Professor Desai was very good in teaching coding content and making it engaging. I actually enjoyed learning SAS and can walk away from the class comfortable with the skills that I learned.

Mayur does a good job in his teaching. I feel like I have a strong grasp on the material because of his teaching. He is straight-forward in what he wants on tests and labs. He does a good job of taking skills learned and testing them.

Professor was a good instructor. He was invested in his students, and he was a dynamic lecturer. He was one of the best STEM professors I have had. I appreciated his prompt and helpful responses to emails as well as his willingness to make time for his students outside of class. Moreover, I think the midterm and final exams were fair.
Very clear and enthusiastic!
I love Mayur!!! He is so approachable and kind, very helpful to students!

Hes a tough instructor but very helpful and understanding. I really appreciated his help and flexibility when I was struggling. Just be very open to him and he will want to help you. I thank him very much for that.

Dr. Desai taught his class with a sense of humor which was certainly appreciated. He slides were clear, with SAS code explained and typed right on the slide with the output on the next slide which made it easy to follow. Making it the material relatable and occasionally repeating the same code or concept was also useful as reinforcement.
Dr. Mayur is an excellent lecturer, his lectures are easily to follow and outline the coding in a way that makes sense with the statistical properties that were learning.

Mayur teaches to the level of someone with no SAS background, which I greatly appreciated! He also does an excellent job teaching both stats/epi methods while at the same time teaching us how to apply those methods in SAS. In other words, Mayur's teaching bolstered my knowledge of both the theory and application, which I think is rare for a single course to do! Sometimes I felt Mayur was a little crass and overly sarcastic with his jokes, which for me created a somewhat negative learning environment.
He is funny, knowledgable, and knows how to make a subject that could be really dry and difficult, entertaining and more importantly, easy to understand.
good
Interesting lectures, funny, and the structure of the course was super clear!
Excellent instructor! A great lecturer and cares a lot about the students. He does a very good job of developing clear teaching materials and has structured the course very well.
Mayur is obviously a great teacher and he knows it.
He is excellent. That's why he won the teaching award again!

Dr. Desai was a good professor. He knows the material well and truly wants students to know it and understand it. Some of his examples were a bit harsh at times, and some of my peers and I felt he did come of as a little bit paternal/patronizing at times, but we never thought he did so on purpose or with mal intent. His instruction has allowed us all to have a great understanding of SAS, but I think he could be an even better instructor if he did more to make the lecture hall feel a bit more comfortable.

Mayur does not assume that students have significant prior knowledge of or exposure to any statistical programming packages. He starts with teaching the fundamentals and works his way up. The information he presents in lecture and on his slides is extremely clear and understandable. A great instructor overall.
Mayur is a really engaging instructor. He makes the data analysis interesting and easier to understand.
na
This course is helpful for learning how to do preliminary analyses in SAS. I would recommend it if you feel you can't learn SAS on your own or need an introduction.
Definitely recommend! It's a great introduction to SAS especially for those with zero coding experience

DEFINITELY RECOMMEND! This will probably be the most useful course you take at YSPH. I gained so much confidence about my quantitative abilities after taking this class. It's hard but very, very useful.
Would recommend unreservedly.

I would explain to a fellow student that this course is similar to a language class, in which there is a steep learning curve, but if you allocate the proper amount of time you are left with a strong skillset. I would absolutely recommend this class.
I would highly recommend this course after the summer intensive Biostats course.

While this course is presented as straightforward and that you're "told everything you need to know," I didn't entirely find this to be my actual experience. Learning SAS coding as someone with zero SAS experience was like teaching myself Greek from scratch...while being asked to analyze high-level Greek at the same time. I was led to believe that this was the most pragmatic and useful choice of the AAMIE/Biostats II/Epi II trifecta, but as someone who struggles deeply with quantitative coursework, I think taking this course was a mistake.  

Looking back, I appreciate the practical skills I learned, but wish I had trusted my gut and taken Biostats II instead.
highly applied way of using epi and biostats, a must for ppl interested in epi and biostats, and research
This course is an introduction to epidemiological data analysis in SAS. Application is emphasized. I would highly recommend this course to anyone working with large datasets.

Introduction to using SAS/quantitative epidemiology class. Yes, I would recommend this class to other students. It is highly relevant to public health research. And I'm sure that it will come in handy for my thesis.
Boring but useful.
I highly recommend this course if you want a beginner's-level course on conducting analyses in SAS. It's a practical course, and you walk away with a basic understanding on how to use SAS.
Would recommend! It's a lot of work but you learn a lot and leave actually knowing how to use SAS.

Highly recommend. You walk through the whole process of data analysis from exploratory data analysis to building regression models. It helps build in the mentality for data analysis and addressing issues you might run into.
I would highly recommend it if you want practical SAS skills!
Definitely recommend.
Good for a quick overview in SAS.

If you hated Mike Winniger's biostats, you'll like this class. It was manageable, very applied, and could be rewarding. I would recommend it to any student that has the option to choose between Biostats 2, Epi 2 and this. It is the easy of the three and doesn't require excessive amounts of time.
I would highly recommend this course to other students. It is an enjoyable way to learn a new statistical analysis tool that otherwise may seem tedious to approach.
a necessity for any epi student. a necessary skill.

This is a really useful course if you don't have much experience with stats software and want to get an intro so that the coding feels less intimidating. It's really useful for learning how to run analyses for theses/side projects as well.
Great class to learn SAS with realy data sets. Try not to cry if you never get a 3/3.
Learned the most Ive learned at YSPH from this classgood to have hard skills as a takeaway!
This is the course for students without previous knowledge in SAS. It teaches from the basics, so would not be difficult to understand. I would definitely recommend this course to another student.
I highly recommend this course if you want to learn how to use SAS.
Strongly recommend this course
Learnt a lot
I highly recommend this course because you come out of it learning very relevant and important skills.

If you don't have a good SAS background, it would be good to study it a little more. Exams are take home and do take some time (you get one week, but would not recommend waiting until the last couple of days to work on it unless you're very good with SAS).

I would definitely recommend this course, which is a basic but important lesson for SAS analysis. It emphasized on precision and checking the data. It's quite helpful in terms of cultivating good coding habits.
Very useful for SAS tyro.
I would recommend this course to another student, I just wish there was a way to make the actual lecture portions more interactive (in addition to lab).
I feel that it teaches an important skill and Professor Desai manages to teach it in an entertaining and engaging manner.
I would highly recommend.

You will be given the opportunity to learn SAS and if you do it as instructed and take advantage of office hours you will do fine. The final and midterm are very hard but make you think critically. Start them early-you will need more time than you think. My alumni mentor said this was the most useful course she ever took and I agree
Amazing and useful coursework.
I would recommend, very useful skill to have.

I would highly recommend this course anyone who is planning to work with data. In fact, even if you are not planning to manage data, it is still helpful because it shows you how to read the results of a paper.

Excellent course! I would 100% recommend taking this course even if your program of study does not require you to take it. You will learn very useful and applied methods in analyzing epidemiological data. It is likely to prepare you well for your thesis and future research.
If you want to learn SAS, would recommend!

I would recommend AAMIE to fellow students. The content is approachable, the structure is relatable, and the skills students are provided are critical to succeeding in the 21st century. SAS is a great skill to have - understanding data and data analysis will continue to be selling points for future graduates.I believe this course should be required for all students pursuing an MPH, regardless of their concentration. MPH students would benefit from other courses that provide exposure to programming and statistical analysis (R and SPSS in particular) with a similar structure to this course.

a good and useful course
Yes, because it can help students learn a lot about SAS.
This class is an absolute must for anyone who might be doing statistical analysis in the future using a computer (which is everyone)!
Very useful, especially for those pursing quantitative careers.
very helpful
I would recommend

Mayurs slides on SAS fundamentals are thorough and useful. I will definitely be using the information for my internship this summer and as a result would definitely recommend to another student hoping to gain analytic skills
Highly recommend due to its organization and ground up nature.
HIGHLY practical for research. Important for structuring how to ask epi research questions and conduct foundational calculations in epi. I began as a SAS padawan but emerged a master.
If you want to learn data analysis using SAS, you should definitely take this class! I definitely improved my quantitative data analysis skills.
This course is a must-take. Through this course, I feel like I have a strong grasp on SAS and how to effectively code and analyze data.

I would recommend this course to anyone who has a little to no background in SAS coding and would like to build an strong foundation. I would also recommend this to someone who would like to learn about some of the most common statistical methods used in journal articles.
A good class that you also probably have to take.
Its a tough class but you will have felt like you learned how to use SAS quite well at the end of the day. I would recommend taking it.

This is a great course that I would highly recommend as the instructor is great and teaches the material and SAS with ease making it easy to understand by the student. Lab sessions also help a great deal to reinforce the coding and fully understand the material.
Take it. If you want to bolster your quantitative skills or learn how to use SAS, take this class.

I definitely recommend this course if you're looking for an introduction to SAS. I gained solid skills and more confidence in SAS (which I think has also boosted my confidence using other statistical analysis packages).
Great course on how to use SAS to conduct data analysis in public health and epidemiology
good

Definitely take this course!  One of the best, and most applied courses at YSPH.  
It's a lot of work and can be frustrating at times because of the sheer level of perfection required to do well, but worth it!
This course is an applied introductory course on data analysis with a focus on programming with SAS software. I would highly recommend this course!
Yes take it and learn at least one useful technical skill during your MPH
Great course to learn data management. Likely  one of the best courses at the school of public health and best use of your tuition money:)

If you want a great basic understanding of SAS, this is the course for you. By the time you leave you'll be able to fire up SAS and not have to refer to notes to know what to do, you'll have the confidence to take on any data set. The statistical tests learned are perfect for pubic health students, so I would recommend the course to anyone and everyone.

An extremely practical course that should be required for any students who may not be competent in using a statistical programming package. Definitely see myself using the skills in gained in this course well in to the future. Highly recommend.
Good course if trying to use and apply SAS more for research. By the end of the course, I was able to do basic statistical analysis for research studies in the future.
recommend it for gaining useful skills in public health
